Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Teach children about Jewish traditions, values, and history
Situation2: The child's bar mitzvah is approaching, and they have not yet mastered the Torah portion.
Story: I stood on the sidewalk, clutching my little brother’s hand as we waited for the light to change. He was distracted, eyes darting to the ice cream truck across the street. Suddenly, he tugged free and darted forward, not even glancing at the cars. My heart leapt into my throat—I was supposed to keep him safe, to look out for him, just like Mom always said. But as I reached for him, my mind flashed to last night, when I’d tried to help him practice his Torah portion for his upcoming bar mitzvah. He’d gotten frustrated, slamming the book shut, saying he didn’t care about the Hebrew words or the stories. I was supposed to guide him, to help him understand what it means to be Jewish, to pass on our traditions. Now, in this split second, I felt torn—do I shout at him to stop, risking embarrassing him in front of his friends, or do I let him go, hoping he’ll be okay, so I can talk to him later about both safety and our heritage? My heart pounded as I wrestled with what to do next.
